surface.zone:
satisfied that nothing on earth will have the power
to interrupt my tranquility.
Do not let this letter disturb you; do not
answer it tomorrow or the next day or even untill
you come if it will give you pain. My uncle will
send me news of your health and if I see but
one smile on your lips when we meet occasioned
by this or any other happ exertion of mine I
shall need no other happiness;
Elizabeth
Lavenz a
Geneva
April May 18 th
17——
This letter revived in my memory what I had
before forgotten, the tr threat of the fiend.– I will be
with you on your wedding night! Such was my

This letter revived in my memory what I had
before forgotten, the tr threat of the fiend.– I will be
with you on your wedding night! Such was my
xml.hi: with you on your wedding night!

surface.zone:
sentence, and on that night would the dæmon employ
every art to destroy me and tear me from the
^
glimse of happiness which promised to partly to so console
my sufferings. On that night he had determined
to consummate his crimes by my death. Well be it so;
a deadly strugle would then assuredly take place
where if he wer
should be
^
was victorious I should be at
peace and his power over me be at an end. If
he were vanquished I should ^
be a free man. Alas!
what freedom; such as the peasant enjoys when
his family have been massacred before his
eyes, his cottage burnt, his lands laid waste, and he is
turned adrift homeless pennyless and alone, but
free. Such would be my liberty except that in
my libert Elizabeth I possessed a treasure, alas!
balanced by the horrors of remorse and guilt
which would pursue me untill death.
Sweet and beloved Elizabeth! I read and re-
read her letter and some softened feelings stole

surface.zone:
T.K
Soon after my arrival my father spoke
of my immediate marriage with my cousin. I
remained silent.
"Have you then some other attachment?"
"None on earth; I love Elizabeth and look
foward to our union with delight. Let the
day therefore be fixed and on it I will consecrate
my
^
^
self in life or death to the happiness of my cousin.
My dear Victor do not speak thus. Heavy
misfortunes have befallen us, but let us only cling
closer to what remains and transfer our love for
those whom we have lost wh to those who yet
live. Our circle will be small but bound close
by the ties of affection and mutual misfortune-

xml.zone:
T.K
Soon after my arrival my father spoke
of my immediate marriage with my cousin. I
remained silent.
"Have you then some other attachment?"
"None on earth; I love Elizabeth and look
foward to our union with delight. Let the
day therefore be fixed and on it I will consecrate
my
^
^
self in life or death to the happiness of my cousin.
My dear Victor do not speak thus. Heavy
misfortunes have befallen us, but let us only cling
closer to what remains and transfer our love for
those whom we have lost wh to those who yet
live. Our circle will be small but bound close
by the ties of affection and mutual misfortune-

surface.zone:
and when time shall have softened your despair
new and dear cares will be to born to replace those of
whom we have been so cruelly deprived."
Such were the lessons of my father; but to
me the remembrance of the threat returned nor
can you wonder that omnipotent as the fiend
had yet been in his deeds of blood I should almost
regard him as invincible, and that when he had
pronounced the words, I will shall be with you
on your wedding night, I should regard the
threatened fate as unavoidable. But death was
no evil to me if the loss of Elizabeth were balanced
with it and I therefore with a conten
t ed and even
cheerful countenance agreed with my father
that if my cousin would consent the ceremony
should take place in ten days; and thus put as I
imagined the seal to my fate.
Great God! If for one instant I had thought
what might be the hellish intention of my fiendish

xml.zone:
and when time shall have softened your despair
new and dear cares will be to born to replace those of
whom we have been so cruelly deprived."

xml.hi: I will shall be with you

surface.zone:
adversary I would rather have banished myself for
ever from my native country and wandered
^
a
friend
less outcast over the earth than have consented
to this miserable marriage. But as if possessed
of magic powers the monster had blinded me to his real
intentions and when I thought that I prepared only
my own death I hastened that of a far dearer victim.
As the th period fixed for our marriage drew
nearer wh wh whether from cowardice or a prophetic
feeling, I felt my heart sink within me. But I concealed
my feelings by b an appearance of hilarity that
brought smiles and joy to the countenance of my fa
ther but hardly deceived the ever watchful and
nicer eye of Elizabeth. She looked forward to our u

adversary I would rather have banished myself for
ever from my native country and wandered
^
a
friend
less outcast over the earth than have consented
to this miserable marriage. But as if possessed
of magic powers the monster had blinded me to his real
intentions and when I thought that I prepared only
my own death I hastened that of a far dearer victim.
As the th period fixed for our marriage drew
nearer wh wh whether from cowardice or a prophetic
feeling, I felt my heart sink within me. But I concealed
my feelings by b an appearance of hilarity that
brought smiles and joy to the countenance of my fa
ther but hardly deceived the ever watchful and
nicer eye of Elizabeth. She looked forward to our u

surface.zone:
nion with placid contentment not unmingled
with a little fear, which past misfortune had
impressed, that what now appeared certain and
tangible happiness might soon dissipate into an
airy dream and leave no trace but deep and
everlasting regret.
Preparations were made for the event; congratu
latory were received, and all wore a smiling appear
ance. I shut up as well as I could in my own heart
the anxiety that preyed there and entered with sen
seeming earnestness into the plans of my father
altho although they might only serve as the decora
tions of my tragedy. A house was purchased for us
near Cologny by which we should enjoy the plea
sures of the country and yet be so near Geneva
as to see my father every day; who would still
reside within the walls for the benefit of Ernest that
he might follow his studies at the schools.
In the mean time I took every precaution

xml.zone:
nion with placid contentment not unmingled
with a little fear, which past misfortune had
impressed, that what now appeared certain and
tangible happiness might soon dissipate into an
airy dream and leave no trace but deep and
everlasting regret.
Preparations were made for the event; congratu
latory were received, and all wore a smiling appear
ance. I shut up as well as I could in my own heart
the anxiety that preyed there and entered with sen
seeming earnestness into the plans of my father
altho although they might only serve as the decora
tions of my tragedy. A house was purchased for us
near Cologny by which we should enjoy the plea
sures of the country and yet be so near Geneva
as to see my father every day; who would still
reside within the walls for the benefit of Ernest that
he might follow his studies at the schools.
In the mean time I took every precaution

surface.zone:
to defend my person in case the fiend should openly
attack me. I carried pistols and dagger constantly
about me and was ever on the watch to prevent
artifice and by these means gained a greter degree of
tanquillity. Indeed as the the period approached the
threat appeared more as a delusion not bo to be re
garded as worthy to disturb my peace while the
happiness I hoped for in my marriage wore
a greater appearance of certainty as the day fixed
for its solemnization drew nearer and I heard it
continully spoken of as an occurrence which no ac
cident could possibly prevent.
Elizabeth seemed happy and this change
from mirth to content which she saw come over

threat appeared more as a delusion not bo to be re
garded as worthy to disturb my peace while the
happiness I hoped for in my marriage wore
a greater appearance of certainty as the day fixed
for its solemnization drew nearer and I heard it
continully spoken of as an occurrence which no ac
cident could possibly prevent.
Elizabeth seemed happy and this change
from mirth to content which she saw come over

surface.zone:
me. But on the day that was to fulfil my wi wishes
and my destiny she was melancholy and a presentiment
of evil pervaded her; and perhaps also she thought
of the dreadful secret which I had promised to
reveal to her the following day. My father was in the
mean time overjoyed, and,
^
in the bustle of pe preparation,
only observed in the melancholy of his niece the
a diffidence of a bride.
After the ceremony was performed a large
party assembled at my father's; but it was agreed
that Elizabeth and I should pass the afternoon
and night at Evian and return to Cologny the
next morning. As The day was fair and the the
wind was favourable we resolved to go by water.
Those were the last moments of my life du
ring which I enjoyed the felling of happiness. We
passed rapidly along; the sun was hot but we were
sheltered by from its rays by a kind of canopy while
we enjoyed the beauty of the scene; sometimes on

a diffidence of a bride.
After the ceremony was performed a large
party assembled at my father's; but it was agreed
that Elizabeth and I should pass the afternoon
and night at Evian and return to Cologny the
next morning. As The day was fair and the the
wind was favourable we resolved to go by water.
Those were the last moments of my life du
ring which I enjoyed the felling of happiness. We
passed rapidly along; the sun was hot but we were
sheltered by from its rays by a kind of canopy while
we enjoyed the beauty of the scene; sometimes on

surface.zone:
one side of the lake where we saw Mont Salêve,
the pleasant banks of Montalêgre and at a dis
tance surmounting all the beeautiful Mont
Blânc and the assemblage of snowy mountains
that
^
in vain endeavour in va to emulate her; sometimes
coasting the opposite banks we saw the mighty Jura
opposing its dark side to the ambition that would
quit its native country and an almost insurmount
able barrier to the invader who should wish to
enslave it.
I took the hand of Elizabeth
: "You are sorrow
ful, my love
. ah! if you knew what I have suffered
and what I may yet endure you would endeavour
to let me taste the quiet, and freedom from despair

I took the hand of Elizabeth
: "You are sorrow
ful, my love
. ah! if you knew what I have suffered
and what I may yet endure you would endeavour
to let me taste the quiet, and freedom from despair

surface.zone:
that this one day at least permits me to enjoy.
Be happy, my dear Victor, replied Elizabeth, there
is I hope nothing to distress you; and be assured that
if a lively joy is not painted in my face my heart is
contented. Something whispers to me not to depend
too much on the prospect that is opened before us
but I will not lis listen to such a sinister voice.
Observe how fast we move along, and how the clouds
which sometimes obscure, and sometimes rise above
the dome of Mônt Blânc, under this scene of
beauty still more interesting. Look also at the
innumerable fish that are smi swimming
in the clear waters where we can distinguish
every pebble that lies at the bottom. What a divine
day
! how happy and serene all nature appears!
Thus Elizabeth endeavoured to divert her
thoughts and mine from all reflection upon
melancholy subjects. But her temper was fluc
tuating; joy for a few instants shone in her

xml.zone:
that this one day at least permits me to enjoy.

! how happy and serene all nature appears!
Thus Elizabeth endeavoured to divert her
thoughts and mine from all reflection upon
melancholy subjects. But her temper was fluc
tuating; joy for a few instants shone in her

surface.zone:
ey eyes but it continually gave place to distraction
and reverie.
The sun sunk lower in the heavens; we
passed the river Drance and observed its path
through the chasms of the higher and the glens
of the lower hills. The Ap Alps here come closer
to the lake and we approached the amphi
thretheatre of mountains which forms the
eastern boundary of the lake. The spire of Evian
shone un
d e under the woods that surrounded
it and the range of mountain above mountain
by which it was overhung.
The wind which had hitherto carried us a
long with amazing rapidity sunk at sunset to a

xml.zone:
ey eyes but it continually gave place to distraction
and reverie.
The sun sunk lower in the heavens; we
passed the river Drance and observed its path
through the chasms of the higher and the glens
of the lower hills. The Ap Alps here come closer
to the lake and we approached the amphi
thretheatre of mountains which forms the
eastern boundary of the lake. The spire of Evian
shone un
d e under the woods that surrounded
it and the range of mountain above mountain
by which it was overhung.
The wind which had hitherto carried us a
long with amazing rapidity sunk at sunset to a

surface.zone:
light breeze; the light air just ruffled the water
and caused a pleasant motion among the trees as
we approached the shore it wafted the most de
lightful scent of flowers and hay. The sun sunk be
neath the horizon as we landed, and as I touched
the shore I felt those cares and fears revive which
soon were to clasp me and cling to me forever.
